Jack Cates.Action: Engages in a tense interaction with Elaine Marshall, showing a playful and self-deprecating sense of humor despite the seriousness of the situation.
Approaches woman with gun drawn and accuses her without explaining or answering her questions.
Stealthily moves up a stairwell with gun ready, carefully listens for sounds before advancing.
Rips open the shower curtain with gun aimed, promptly revealing the suspect.
Turns off water upon revealing the woman, indicating control of the situation.
Uses intimidating dialogue referencing a .44 Magnum to assert authority and control.
Spins the gun's cylinder and admits it's not loaded during confrontation.
Throws his robe to Elaine to wear after she takes off his shirt, sharing what little he has.
Keeps brushing teeth after Elaine says the toothbrush is hers, somewhat dismissive.
Stops brushing, looks at Elaine and sincerely says 'I'm here...' after she says she doesn't know when he'll be back.
Wakes up promptly to his alarm, quickly gets dressed and prepares for the day.
Exchanges banter with Elaine showing a casual confidence and control in the relationship.
Continues brushing his teeth despite Elaine's comment about toothbrush ownership, showing a mix of inattentiveness or dismissal.
Responds calmly and reassures Elaine when she questions his presence, showing confidence and steady interpersonal engagement.
Asks for coffee politely ('Please').
Pours whiskey into coffee without discussing it; somewhat dismissive.
Responds defensively and harshly to Elaine's suggestion ('Maybe you don't know what the hell you’re talking about').
Acknowledges the intimate relationship and emotional connection ('I'm the guy in your bed the last three months. I make you feel good. You make me feel good.').
Turns away and says he doesn't have time; appears emotionally distant ('I don't have time for this. I gotta go to work.').
Admits it's hard to apologize but expresses gladness to be in her life ('Look, I'm glad I'm in your life...').
Uses playful, somewhat crude humor to lighten the mood ('...with an ass like yours, I figure anything might be possible').
Pours whiskey into coffee to start his day, indicating possible reliance on alcohol to cope with stress.
Straps on his holstered .44 before going to work, showing readiness and preparation for his job.
Engages in a tense, somewhat defensive conversation with Elaine, showing emotional conflict and reluctance to open up.
States 'I don't have time for this. I gotta go to work,' reflecting focus on his responsibilities despite personal issues.
His attempt at humor and warmth with Elaine suggests some social competence though mixed with self-deprecation.
Moves closer and kisses Elaine when she seems uncertain, showing a gentle, sincere gesture.
Thanks Elaine for the coffee politely, indicating good-natured behavior.
Acknowledges Elaine’s caring act of putting a scarf around his neck with a nod of appreciation, showing tolerance and friendliness.
Shoves a parking ticket in his coat pocket and curses quietly, showing frustration but no hostility towards others.
Keeps his composure despite noticing and receiving a parking ticket, calmly puts it in his coat pocket and proceeds to start the car and drive away.
Shows awareness of his identity and authority by not forgetting his wallet and badge, and acknowledging that people ought to know who he is.
Engages warmly and appreciatively with Elaine but does not kiss her, showing emotional control and situational awareness.
Does not act on irritation about the parking ticket, avoids confrontation or distraction, and instead focuses on driving off.
Casually greets colleagues with friendly banter and smiles at the usual ribbing.
Offers to help out despite being told to stay out, expressing willingness to contribute.
Shows frustration and accepts to step back from the investigation without complaint.
Offers to help colleagues with a case even when they suggest he stay out of it.
Acknowledges the politics and steps back without causing conflict, showing situational awareness.
Engages in light verbal sparring but maintains professionalism and does not escalate the situation.
Does not push to take control or demonstrate leadership when sidelined by colleagues.
Nudges Frizzy aside and uses a sexist insult ('dumb skirt') to get information quickly.
Takes initiative to find the name in the register and inform the team.
Agreeing reluctantly to stake out the lobby with sarcastic attitude ('Sure. Great. Whatever.'), showing minimal enthusiasm.
Nudges Frizzy aside and efficiently starts going through the register book to find relevant information.
Finds the name Polson and identifies the room number quickly from the register book.
Complies with the order to stake out the lobby though with some apparent indifference ('Sure. Great. Whatever.'), showing readiness but perhaps lack of enthusiasm.
Moves to get a vantage point at the foot of the stairwell, strategically positioning himself to see the entire lobby and all angles, including a specific target (Frizzy).
Races up stairs three at a time, takes next flight in two jumps, showing agility and quick response.
Flies into the lobby and quickly neutralizes Ganz by slamming him twice with his pistol, demonstrating physical dominance and tactical decisiveness.
Senses ambush instinctively and moves just as Billy fires, effectively avoiding gunfire.
Starts back down toward the lobby after seeing injured Algren and Vanzant, possibly missing an opportunity to immediately pursue the fleeing suspects with Algren’s assistance.
Hesitates to shoot when Rosalie is threatened, lowers his gun instead.
Cradles dead Algren's head and stares at arriving police.
Calls Ganz a 'lying son of a bitch' after ambush.
Twists sideways just as Ganz fires, avoiding a bullet.
Attempts to grab Algren's gun despite dangerous situation.
Leaps into a phone booth to take cover under fire.
Ends up wedged tightly at the top of the phone booth, unable to immediately escape.
Drops to the floor and quickly recovers after phone booth is shot up.
Rushes to Algren after police arrive, but is too late to save him.
Responds briefly and curtly to the detectives' questions, showing frustration but deferring to official report.
Dismisses young cop's concerns brusquely, telling him to 'just shut the fuck up' after a tense confrontation.
Acknowledges mistakes bluntly, admitting the killed cops 'fucked up and got careless.'
Takes responsibility for the situation without deflecting, despite tensions from other officers.
Acknowledges that the dead cops were good but made a critical mistake, showing honest assessment of the situation.
Shows impatience and dismissiveness toward a younger cop's comments on procedure, telling him not to give him crap.
Physically intimidates a younger cop who criticizes him, then quickly regains composure.
Efficiently obtains a gun from the Old Cop and confirms instructions from Haden, showing readiness and focus.
Shows interest in Lisa's statement and engages in questioning her smoothly.
Uses a somewhat sarcastic remark 'Maybe he didn't like your performance....' when questioning Lisa.
Responds to Lisa's insult with a light, non-hostile comment ('I'll take a raincheck...').
Displays pragmatic, somewhat dry humor when discussing bad people ('If there weren't, what would there be for us to do?').
Offers practical help to Kehoe in going through the suitcase without hesitation.
Quickly reviews photos and matches gun evidence to the crime scenes, showing understanding of the forensic details.
Initially says 'I don't get it' when presented with forensic photos, indicating some confusion or lack of immediate understanding.
Responds to Ruth's grim observation with a confident, almost philosophical comment about their work, demonstrating composure and confidence.
Notices and reacts promptly to Kehoe entering with a suitcase, indicating awareness and readiness to engage.
Offers to help Kehoe go through the suitcase without hesitation, showing initiative and teamwork.
Shares mug shot files with Ruth and Kehoe so they can see together, showing transparency and collaboration.
Ignores Haden's call repeatedly before finally complying, indicating some reluctance to authority.
Expresses desire to discuss the suspects who are still free, showing willingness to engage and resolve issues cooperatively.
Tells Haden he wants to be left alone on the case because Algren was killed with his gun, which may suggest feeling isolated but also sincerity about personal responsibility.
Carefully examines files and mug shots, cross-referencing forensic evidence with suspect photos, demonstrating thoroughness and attention to detail.
Recognizes the significance of the .44 speed loader and shells, understanding its link to him, showing situational awareness.
Shows initiative by wanting to discuss suspects still at large and finding their whereabouts, indicating proactive investigative thinking.
Initially ignores Haden's order to come in immediately but later complies, demonstrating controlled assertiveness rather than impulsive insubordination.
Expresses concern that cops get hurt while he's making a play, saying 'I don't like it.'
Almost smiles at Haden despite tense conversation, showing some friendliness.
Refuses to fully cooperate with team advice, insists on doing things his own way.
Responds sarcastically to Haden's warnings, displaying a somewhat dismissive attitude.
Asserts ownership of his gun and insists on retrieving it despite department pressure.
Acknowledges concern about cops getting hurt during his operations, showing situational awareness.
Refuses to be a team player and prefers to do things his own way, showing confidence but potential disregard for collaboration.
Receives stern warning from superior and proceeds with a lead despite risks, displaying confident initiative.
Responds to warnings with sarcasm and humor, potentially downplaying seriousness of his actions.
Hands Elaine a hot dog and shares a moment of casual conversation.
Refuses to recuperate at Elaine's place despite her concern, prioritizing reclaiming his gun.
Expresses deep personal responsibility and frustration about the consequences of his lost gun.
Dismisses Elaine's attempt to offer emotional support, using blunt and macho language.
Explains to Elaine that the job comes first, everything else second, in a blunt manner.
Declines the guard's offer for company, preferring to be alone while approaching inmates.
Observes Reggie Hammond's cell with a bit of surprise and acknowledges Hammond's sense of style, nodding politely to the guard.
Insists on taking responsibility for catching the criminal using his stolen gun, showing resolve and ownership.
Refuses the guard's offer for company when entering the prison cell block, indicating confidence and self-reliance.
Observes the cell block and inmate's surroundings carefully, noting details indicating intelligence and attention to environment.
Requests to talk privately with Hammond, acknowledging knowledge of his situation, and tentatively asks for help.
Mocks Hammond by calling him not smart because he is a convict.
Uses the override button on the Sony to get Hammond's attention, demonstrates control over the environment.
Engages Hammond directly and attempts to gather information about him and his background, showing interrogation skills.
Displays some street smarts and awareness of Hammond’s situation to try to persuade him to cooperate.
Mocks Hammond’s intelligence by saying 'if you were real smart you wouldn't be a convict,' possibly alienating the subject and risking cooperation.
Dismisses Hammond's concerns and calls them 'bullshit.'
Considers Hammond's offer to deliver Ganz despite initial skepticism.
Smiles while being confrontational and sarcastic.
Refuses to seriously engage or show empathy to Hammond's situation.
Keeps calm and collected when dealing with Hammond, shows confidence in handling tricky situations by teasing and managing Hammond's requests.
Acknowledges complexity of the Ganz situation immediately, demonstrating awareness of important facts and street smarts.
Considers Hammond's offer pragmatically ('I'll think about it'), indicating cautious decision-making rather than impulsiveness.
Uses false name for documents, indicating strategic thinking and understanding of undercover or covert operations.
Signs documents quickly and hands them over while maintaining composure and a casual attitude.
Responds confidently to Bob's warnings with a calm 'no sweat' attitude.
Double checks orders with the guard before unlocking Hammond's cuffs, showing attention to procedure.
Comments on Hammond's expensive suit, indicating some confusion about the prison environment and priorities.
Refuses to be manipulated by Hammond's attempt to bargain, showing firmness and sincerity.
Makes clear to Hammond that they are not friends or partners, insisting on a strictly professional relationship.
Slaps handcuffs on Hammond and himself, demonstrating control of the situation rather than entering into a naive partnership.
Clearly states his intent to keep Hammond restrained and in check until they capture Ganz, showing strategic thinking and decisiveness.
Leads Hammond confidently out of jail to his car, taking initiative in the next steps.
Rejects Hammond's attempts at friendly negotiation or partnership openly, maintaining focus on the mission.
Insists on being called by his real name and objects to 'Jack' in a somewhat brusque but honest way.
Engages in playful insults with Hammond, exchanging 'shithead' and 'asshole' in a way that suggests camaraderie.
Takes control of the situation by handcuffing Hammond to the door handle and taking car keys, showing distrust and caution.
Smiles when agreeing to lend a gun to Hammond despite the tense situation.
Double-checks his .38 before approaching a dangerous location.
Handcuffs Hammond to the door handle and takes car keys, effectively controlling the situation.
Argues about being called 'Jack' but maintains focus on the mission and drives off confidently.
Dismisses Hammond's warning about Luther being unreliable but proceeds cautiously.
Commands Hammond to drop the gun firmly and calmly during a tense standoff.
Shows trust in Hammond by asking him to throw the gun despite the dangerous situation.
Cautiously tries the door knob and enters alone, showing tactical awareness and caution.
Drops to a crouch and aims his weapon immediately when confronted by Luther with a gun, demonstrating quick reflexes and combat readiness.
Commands Hammond firmly to drop the gun in a tense situation, showing assertiveness and control.
Relies on Hammond, who is cuffed to a door handle, to subdue Luther instead of taking immediate direct action himself.
Pulls himself up using Luther's belly and cuffs him; uses physical force (slams car door into Luther) during interrogation.
Engages in rough but somewhat playful banter with Hammond after hitting Luther with the car door.
Uses intimidation and physical aggression to get information from Luther.
Cuffs Luther efficiently and prepares him for questioning, demonstrating control of the situation.
Uses physical intimidation (slamming the car door against Luther) effectively to coerce information.
Keeps focus on extracting useful information, challenges Luther's lies confidently.
Engages in somewhat aggressive behavior that risks escalating conflict, but manages it skillfully.
Wrestles Luther into the back seat to control the situation and prevent him from running to warn Ganz.
Firm with Hammond, insults him but keeps control of the situation.
Makes sure to keep Luther under custody and plans to file a detailed report, showing responsibility.
Tells Hammond to stay with him, implying he does not fully trust him but wants to keep an eye on him.
Questions the situation and suspects something is wrong despite incomplete information.
Decides to keep Luther detained and insists he must take the call; shows strategic thinking.
Physically restrains Luther when he makes a move toward Hammond, maintaining control.
Criticizes Hammond's plan bluntly and confidently, suggesting confidence in his own assessment.
Files multiple charges on Luther, including thinking to add more later, showing thoroughness.
Immediately seizes the initiative to follow up with a phone call and makes Hammond stay close for support.
Picks up the phone promptly and identifies himself clearly.
Communicates efficiently under pressure and maintains control of the situation at booking.
Avoids expressing personal feelings and declines to visit Elaine despite emotional difficulty, focusing on work priorities.
Shows irritability and frustration during conversation with Elaine, indicating some emotional difficulty in managing relationships.
Pulls Hammond away firmly to keep things moving despite Hammond's objection.
Tells Hammond to stop moaning about not getting out to 'hunt' for prostitutes.
Insists on controlling when they eat, initially disregards Hammond's hunger complaints.
Eventually acknowledges Hammond's hunger and suggests they go to a nice place to eat.
Interrupts Hammond to assert control and move the situation forward despite Hammond nearly compromising their position.
Shows leadership by directing Hammond and making decisions on when and where to proceed.
Maintains discipline by insisting they eat only when he says so, showing control over the team and situation.
Eventually concedes to Hammond's demand to eat and chooses a place he knows, balancing strictness with pragmatism.
Throws Hammond a candy bar from the vending machine.
Readjusts Elaine's scarf on the mirror, showing care for her belongings.
Responds curtly and defensive to Hammond's questions about his girlfriend.
Calmly handles situation at candy machine, keeps focus on task by telling Hammond to be quiet and get in the car.
Readjusts Elaine's scarf on the mirror, showing attention to detail and care amid the chaos.
Responds with sarcasm and irritation when Hammond questions him about his personal life, indicating possible defensiveness that might cloud clear communication.
Smiles back at Hammond, almost cruelly, and refuses to share personal details about his girl.
Shows a pained expression when admitting to a fight with his girl, indicating some vulnerability.
Gives Hammond a hard look in response to a crass comment about the girl.
Warns Hammond that if he gets hurt, Hammond will too, implying loyalty and a willingness to protect his partner.
Asserts that attitude and experience matter more than a gun and badge, suggesting a more sincere and grounded outlook.
Maintains a confident and controlled demeanor, smiling almost cruelly and refusing to give out personal details despite pressure.
Acknowledges a tough situation realistically, expressing a pained reaction when discussing a fight, showing situational awareness.
Advises Hammond to back him up with the reason that failure will have bad consequences for both, demonstrating strategic thinking and leadership.
Counters Hammond's dismissive attitude about guns and badges by emphasizing the importance of attitude and experience, showing professional insight.
Engages Hammond in a bet to elicit truthful information, showing a direct but fair approach.
Lightly mocks Hammond about his success with women.
Smiles and says 'My kind of place. I always liked country boys.'
Smiles and calmly finds a table in the corner at a hostile bar without showing visible discomfort or nervousness.
Engages confidently with the environment, showing familiarity and comfort ('My kind of place. I always liked country boys.')
Does not intervene or escalate the confrontation when Hammond causes a scene, allowing Hammond to act, suggesting a strategic withholding of action.
Puts out a leg to trip a fleeing Cowboy, preventing his escape.
Quietly sips his beer instead of intervening more directly as the officer confronts the punks.
Nods and slips out the door after Hammond says he has won the bet, indicating calm confidence and trust in his partner's lead.
Does not intervene or escalate when Hammond provokes the bartender, showing measured restraint and allowing his partner to control the situation.
Acknowledges Hammond's effort and offers a reward despite tension.
Maintains professional, somewhat friendly banter with Hammond.
Calmly attempts to de-escalate a dangerous situation by asking the woman to drop the gun and explaining he is reaching for his badge.
Commands 'Police! Nobody move!' and points his gun, showing authoritative but necessary force.
Leads Hammond confidently to the target location, identifies the female presence quickly through the window, and moves decisively to enter the apartment.
Draws his weapon and commands the occupants to comply with police order upon entering a darkened room, showing control and tactical awareness.
Attempts to de-escalate the confrontation by reaching for his badge and calmly instructing the women not to shoot, demonstrating presence of mind under pressure.
Calmly approaches a suspicious person, shows his badge to establish trust.
Holds out his hand in a non-threatening manner, tries to build cooperation.
Snatches baseball bat out of Sally's hands to prevent escalation of violence.
Firmly requests cooperation but also warns of consequences if refused.
Pushes aggressively for information, challenges uncooperative suspects.
Invites Hammond to join in some activity despite tense situation, tries to keep things moving.
Dismisses Hammond harshly, insults him repeatedly, shows frustration and lack of patience.
Responds to accusations about a third party indifferently, shows cynicism rather than empathy.
Decides to leave the conversation with Hammond and move on to follow up on the case despite frustration.
Criticizes Hammond's abilities and expresses dissatisfaction with Hammond's contributions to the investigation.
Shows frustration and sarcasm over being forced to work with an unsuitable partner instead of being with his girlfriend.
Uses harsh language and insults Hammond, calling him a crook and degrading him with racial slurs.
Shows confident, somewhat playful behavior by smiling after revealing his badge, despite the tense situation.
Demands information aggressively and threatens violence to get answers.
Uses a racial slur toward Hammond before fighting him.
Calmly tries to de-escalate situation with uniformed cops, explaining his identity and situation.
Acknowledges the inconvenience caused and agrees to file a report despite tiredness.
Uses sarcasm and somewhat brusque language ('asshole') with fellow cops.
Shows concern for Hammond by being one step ahead in cleaning up and managing injuries.
Responds humorously to Hammond's aggressive comment, indicating friendly rapport.
Identifies himself clearly as police despite being met with suspicion; calmly explains situation to other officers; insists on filing a report to clarify events.
Admits to being tired and unable to fully comply immediately (does not raise hands), which might momentarily undermine authority.
Maintains control of the situation by directing other officers to handle confused parties and taking responsibility for the paperwork later.
Responds to the First Cop’s irritation with a calm, resigned attitude accepting the burden ("Goes with the territory"), showing professionalism.
Prepares himself pragmatically by taking care of his injury promptly (rolling up wet towel on bleeding gum), demonstrating practical self-care under pressure.
Refuses to be intimidated by Hammond's threats, remains calm and insists on truth.
Acknowledges his pals saved Hammond's ass, showing some honesty and fairness.
Pressures Hammond to come clean immediately, showing no tolerance for dishonesty.
Challenges Hammond to confess immediately and maintains composure despite provocations.
Unmoved by Hammond's intimidation tactics and keeps focus on extracting key info about the money.
Makes a sarcastic remark about putting the story in his report, showing confidence in his position.
Smiles in interaction with Hammond, maintains a merit-based approach but engages in friendly banter.
Rejects Hammond's proposal for an equal split firmly, showing skepticism and no false friendliness.
Refuses to agree to an unequal money split, insisting on merit and keeping control.
Quickly reacts by making a U-turn when Hammond reveals car location was passed unknowingly.
Smiles and maintains a confident demeanor during negotiation, displaying composure.
Passes a cup of coffee and donut to Hammond while staying alert and attentive during the stakeout.
Chides Hammond lightly for sleeping on the job, showing concern for their shared responsibilities.
Comes across as frustrated and somewhat accusatory when he says Hammond knew all along about the money and that he almost got shot twice for nothing.
Analyzes the situation and confronts Hammond about the plan, showing awareness of the risks they took.
Walks into the parking lot tired and haggard but continues to carry out tasks, indicating persistence despite fatigue.
Relies on stimulants (bennies, coffee, whiskey) to stay alert and focused on the job.
Shows frustration and somewhat impulsive blaming Hammond upon realizing much risk was taken unnecessarily, which could indicate momentary lack of composure.
Comments on Luther's behavior in a frank manner, calling him 'too chickenshit' but reporting that he 'got in line' and noting the bondsman, showing candid and straightforward communication.
Immediately reacts to the situation regarding Luther, noting his behavior and presence with insight, indicating alertness and street smarts.
Quickly locates and tails Luther's car, demonstrating ability to follow a suspect skillfully and confidently.
Makes a racially insensitive joke about 'darker people' and foreign jobs.
Mocks Luther's romantic feelings, implying love makes people stupid.
Dismisses deeper feelings and philosophies about women as common sense, showing a cynical attitude.
Admits he is not in the job for fun or enjoyment, but pragmatically does what works.
Dismisses concern about appearance of the job and insults Hammond's class and attire.
Uses sarcasm and insults to criticize Hammond calling him a lowlife and dumb.
Makes sarcastic remarks about Hammond's past and fashion (Goddamn suit, pimping comment)
Blends in with commuters to keep surveillance without causing alarm
Motions to Hammond and coordinates moving in on Ganz to intercept him before he gets deeper into the crowd.
Cannot risk shooting amidst the chaos, showing restraint despite Hammond's urging to shoot or give up the gun.
Attempts to negotiate with Hammond, urging him to stay with him.
Hesitates to shoot Hammond despite danger, showing reluctance to harm.
Creates further panic among passengers while pursuing Ganz with a gun.
Identifies himself as a policeman to prevent violence and tries to avoid escalation with security officer.
Dejected and sitting quietly after incident, possibly reflecting on events.
Hesitates while aiming at Hammond, losing precious time.
Creates panic while moving after Ganz with gun in hand, struggling through terrified passengers, losing more seconds.
Tries to stop Billy, Ganz, and Rosalie boarding train by running for doors but is confronted by security officer and forced to surrender weapon.
Carefully places gun down and raises hands following order, avoiding escalation with security officer.
Sits dejectedly after events, showing possible frustration or realization of failure.
Admits to screwing up and takes responsibility for losing the suspects and the negative outcome.
Shrugs instead of further protesting or blaming others when questioned about failing to stop the shooting.
Walks away quietly after the reprimand without argument or defiance.
Acknowledges failure openly, admits he screwed up multiple times.
Fails to call for backup during a critical incident despite potential consequences.
Loses suspects who escape by running and catching a train.
Shrugs when questioned about inability to prevent shooting; shows lack of control in the situation.

Responds supportively to Kehoe's greeting despite his own rough day.
Dismisses concern about being beaten up with a casual 'bullshit, you heard wrong.'
Watches hopefully for news/calls, showing some vulnerability and openness.
Responds calmly to Kehoe's comment about being beaten up, denies it confidently.
Checks if any calls have come in, shows alertness and initiative.
His excitement vanishes upon receiving the phone, indicating emotional volatility under pressure.
Assures Kehoe he can depend on him to be in tomorrow despite frustration with red tape.
Shouts angrily into the phone demanding to know where someone is.
Apologizes to Elaine and admits he hasn't been acting well lately.
Immediately prioritizes a call from a friend in the Vice Squad despite being interrupted and distracted, showing loyalty and concern.
Rummages frantically and scatters paperwork when searching for the number, displaying urgency but also a slightly impatient or disorganized manner.

Immediately demands the phone number from Kehoe and acts to call it without hesitation.
Rummages through desk in a somewhat chaotic manner scattering paperwork.
Maintains control of conversation and focuses on calling Hammond quickly despite distractions.
Slams down the phone and rushes toward the door but then promptly returns to check another line upon realizing it is dead.

Shrugs off Hammond's information casually and focuses on the task ('We missed.')

Lets Hammond keep his gun without argument, possibly out of fatigue.
Pays Hammond cash to help him pursue Candy despite Hammond's crude behavior.
Decides to let Hammond keep his gun without arguing, showing practical judgment and emotional control.
Apologizes sincerely for his previous racial insult and acknowledges pressures at work, showing self-awareness and responsibility.
Pays Hammond cash quickly to keep the interaction moving and maintain control of the situation.
Observes carefully as Hammond leaves with Candy, maintains vigilance by immediately moving to a phone to make a call.

Accepts Hammond's quick reappearance and follows him without resistance, indicating trust and cooperation.

Speeds up to catch the bus and fires to protect his partner Hammond and stop the assailant.

Reacts with frustration and anger after the failed escape and crash, cursing the situation.

Defends Hammond verbally to Haden, praising Hammond's intelligence and bravery despite criticism.

Throws away Hammond's handcuffs after taking them off.
Tells Elaine not to throw them out despite their rough appearance; shows vulnerability by admitting they've had a hard night.

Shows skepticism or cynicism about the Indian's relationships using dismissive language.

Decides to call the station to gather information promptly.
Warns Hammond not to run off, showing awareness of risks and wanting to maintain control of the situation.
Checks multiple possible locations (airport, train station, bus station, docks) to track suspects, demonstrating thoroughness.
Expresses frustration with lack of leads but remains engaged and communicative.

Shows focus on mission rather than engaging emotionally with those around him, little direct friendliness or warmth shown in interaction.
Shows tactical awareness by directing the group to approach Billy's location cautiously and gathering intelligence from Casey on Billy's whereabouts.

Maintains stealth and caution as he moves through the apartment corridors, demonstrating skill and careful approach.
